skill.name: agent-browser
skill.description: Browser automation for AI agents via inference.sh. Navigate web pages, interact with elements using @e refs, take screenshots, record video. Capabilities: web scraping, form filling, clicking, typing, drag-drop, file upload, JavaScript execution. Use for: web automation, data extraction, testing, agent browsing, research. Triggers: browser, web automation, scrape, navigate, click, fill form, screenshot, browse web, playwright, headless browser, web agent, surf internet, record video
skill.summary: Browser automation for AI agents using Playwright with simple @e element refs for interaction
skill.author: inference-sh-0

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate browser automation skill using Playwright via inference.sh CLI. The static scanner flagged 606 potential issues, but upon evaluation, all findings are false positives: external_commands detections are bash command examples in documentation, network detections are legitimate test URLs, and the heuristic 'dangerous combination' flag describes expected browser automation behavior (network access + code execution + session management). This skill provides standard web automation functionality for AI agents.

low_findings.title: Documentation Contains Shell Command Examples
low_findings.description: The skill documentation includes bash scripts showing CLI usage. Command substitution syntax is for examples, not actual execution.

low_findings.title: Example URLs in Documentation
low_findings.description: Documentation contains test URLs like example.com and google.com - standard practice for technical documentation.

low_findings.title: Browser Session Management
low_findings.description: Skill manages browser sessions including cookies and authentication state. This is core browser automation functionality, not credential access vulnerability.

content.user_title: Automate Browser Tasks with AI Agents
content.value_statement: This skill enables AI agents to automate browser interactions including navigation, form filling, data extraction, and visual recording through a simple @e reference system.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and capture page state with element references
Interact with elements using click, fill, type, select, hover, drag-drop actions
Record browser sessions as video for debugging
Execute custom JavaScript in page context
Manage persistent browser sessions with proxy support
limitations: Requires inference.sh CLI installation and authentication
Session IDs must be managed by the calling application
Element refs become invalid after page navigation
Video recording increases session resource usage

use_cases.title: Automated Form Submission
use_cases.description: Fill and submit web forms programmatically for data entry automation

use_cases.title: Web Content Extraction
use_cases.description: Navigate websites and extract structured data for research or monitoring

use_cases.title: Visual Browser Testing
use_cases.description: Record browser interactions to create visual documentation or debug issues

prompt_templates.title: Open and Navigate
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the agent-browser skill to open [URL] and get the element references for all interactive elements on the page.

prompt_templates.title: Fill Form Fields
prompt_templates.prompt: Using session [SESSION_ID], fill the form field with ref @e1 with the text '[TEXT]', then click the button with ref @e2.

prompt_templates.title: Capture Screenshot
prompt_templates.prompt: Take a full-page screenshot of the current session [SESSION_ID] and save it.

prompt_templates.title: Extract Data After Action
prompt_templates.prompt: Click element @e1 to navigate to the next page, then take a snapshot and extract all heading text from the new page.

output_examples.output: Session started with ID: abc123. Elements found: @e1 [a] "Example Domain", @e2 [h1] "Example Domain", @e3 [p] "This domain is for use..."
Filled @e1 with 'user@example.com', filled @e2 with 'password123', clicked @e3. Navigation detected. Re-snapshot recommended.
Screenshot captured: {base64 encoded image data}, dimensions: 1920x1080

best_practices: Always re-snapshot after navigation to get fresh element references
Use explicit waits after actions that trigger async loading
Close sessions when done to free browser resources
Enable video recording only when needed for debugging
anti_patterns: Using element refs from a previous page without re-snapshotting
Not handling navigation after click actions
Leaking session IDs or not managing session lifecycle
Attempting to interact with elements that may not be visible

faq.question: What is the @e reference system?
faq.answer: Elements on the page are returned with @e prefixes like @e1, @e2. These refs are used to identify which element to interact with. Refs change after each snapshot.

faq.question: Why do I need to re-snapshot after navigation?
faq.answer: When you navigate to a new page, the DOM changes completely. Previous element refs become invalid and new refs must be fetched.

faq.question: Can this skill bypass login pages?
faq.answer: The skill can automate login forms but cannot bypass authentication. It can help maintain logged-in sessions for subsequent operations.

faq.question: Is video recording always enabled?
faq.answer: No, video recording must be explicitly enabled with record_video: true in the open function. It is off by default.

faq.question: What proxy options are available?
faq.answer: The skill supports HTTP, HTTPS, and SOCKS5 proxies with optional authentication via proxy_username and proxy_password.

faq.question: Can I execute custom JavaScript?
faq.answer: Yes, use the execute function to run JavaScript code in the browser context. The result is returned as a string.
